pros: Personal Time Off & Holiday. 403B employer match.
cons: Low Pay. Little to no career advancement. No transparency. Sub-par Executive Leadership. Management lack interpersonal/leadership skills that foster retention and psychological safety. There is nepotism & cronyism & gossip. Talk of mission is rampant but there are no systems or processes in place to reach goals. On paper, this organization looks like a great opportunity, but internally, it is a mess. There is little to no accountability & many people get by with bare minimum. The employees that do their part are usually inundated with tasks to compensate for the slackers.

Deadlines can be overwhelming sometimes but you do get used to functioning in waves of stress and relaxation.

pros: vacation - salary - retirement

Hiring is done based on ethnicity - gotta improve the diversity at all costs! regardless of any ability to DO the job!!  Very bureaucratic - and a lot of red tape.  Admin is afraid to make decisions - things take forever.

pros: Great leadership. Very hard working group. Always willing to assist newer employees. Wonderful people to work with. Overall a positive environment to work and develop expertise. Especially the president, CAO and deans are all ready to help both faculty and students alike.
cons: Not very many but the that come across can be linked to many work places. In fact all the weaknesses seem to turn to be strengths too. For instance when a not so hard working students report instructor for poor grade which is quite often, the leadership end up making it a good experience for all.

job_title: Adult Ed Teacher in Florence, KY
pros: The pay is better for Adult Ed. at Gateway than any other community college in the area.
cons: Management is awful. My boss didn't even show me where my training materials were or tell me what time to come in the next morning. He was not interested in the program at all, but rather, using it as a way to .promote himself within the academic community. We offer several ESL classes, and the teachers are very competent, but the person with the money and power is not interested in maintaing a much-needed program for low income, immigrant populations. He is teaching academic English, and he should be promoting Literacy level classes. He was the worst boss that I have ever had.

pros: Good benefits, variety of postions and roles, a large system with a central headquarters so lots of different opportunities across the statewide network.
cons:
Leadership at headquarters run the system and those politicians are the worst mix of government and education put together. There are lots of good people in the organization, but many bad apple managers ruin the ability to thrive.

No matter how hard you work, will be the most frustrating place to work because of leadership who have misguided priorities and fail to listen to their staff.

review_title: Love the work; hate the instability

review_title: Government job. Steady, but boring, with lots of red tape
job_title: Senior Public Relations Manager in Versailles, KY
pros: It's a steady job, working for state government. There was a nice benefit of extra time off during the Christmas holidays.
cons: Lots of red tape. Took 18 months, or longer, to accomplish even small tasks, such as organizing an event, due to all the signoffs necessary. The marketing department is also a world unto itself within the organization. Raises never occur, because of cuts in state funding. So get the salary you want to start with, because it won't increase unless you get promoted from within, which is rare.

pros: Working with non-traditional students is wonderful.
cons: There are no promotions. Adjuncts are overlooked for promotions and financial opportunity. We feel like we must beg for classes, like dogs beg for leftovers under the dinner table. Instead of hiring a full time instructor--though many are within reach and qualified, they prefer to hire three adjuncts. I have had the same salary for six years.

review_title: Average place to gain a good start
pros: Hires women and minorities for  visible roles. Offers choice of pension or 401K.
cons: Extremely low salaries! Will not give good salaries for your worth; and, especially not for your accomplished education, even though they are an higher education institution!

pros: I like working there - It is a good environment and the students are great.  There is a lot of options for autonomy and I think that it has an ok combination of student-teacher interaction.
cons: The school is very administrative heavy and there should be more focus on faculty hiring. It has come a long way during its growth but there is room for improvement with some management interactions - I think some kind of training is needed to teach personality styles and how to interact.

pros: The colleges in the Kentucky system provide a good education at a reasonable price. The faculty are very qualified and know their subject well.  The colleges offer steady empolyment and good benefits compared to other businesses in the community.
cons: State budget reductions have financially impacted the colleges and have caused the tuition rates to increase to help cover the operating costs.

pros: Great boss, flexible hours, lots of  additional training. It is a fun place to work, well, as fun as a job can be.
cons: Due to various reasons,it is hard to have access to the things that you need to have in order to do your job properly.

review_title: Good Teaching Environment but Challenging Workplace Politics
pros: Most of the classes (at least at the campus I taught) were small but that allowed me to create a more personable classroom experience for my students. I was able to spend one-on-one time in class (as well as time lecturing), so I made sure my students were progressing successfully. Also, the campus I taught at was small, so it was a close-knit community and it was easy to get to know my colleagues and the staff. Lastly, for the most part I was able to pick my own classroom materials, which enabled me to change my class' content semester-by-semester to keep it from growing stale. Overall, I loved teaching here (at least from the teaching aspect of it).
cons:
Firstly, it's very clear that if one doesn't prescribe to a liberal political mindset, one won't be allowed to advance in his/her career. Thus, KCTCS doesn't truly exhibit tolerance as, if you happen to be non-liberal and/or religious in your views, you will be put on the advancement back burner. 

The same holds true for instructors who academically challenge their students. I had a few division chairs tell me to make my classes easier, to not hold them to the same standards as a four-year college would for a similar class. (I taught Humanities courses.) The reason? One was so I could pass more students (so the system valued quantity over quality) and the other was because the system viewed their students as academically inferior to their four-year counterparts. I never heard of such a thing, and it created difficult waters to navigate as I was asked to not lower my standards yet keep them low enough so all of my students passed, even the lazy/apathetic ones who exhibited little to no effort or work ethic.

Lastly, the system as a whole rarely gave raises (every five to seven years, at least as part of my experience) and they are minimal at best (normally around 1%).

Overall, while I loved teaching and working with students here, I became disenchanted by the work environment and eventually resigned.

review_title: Not a lot of room to grow here.
pros: Great Benefits and vacation. Free tuition up to 6 credit hours is a big pro. Good people to work with.
cons: Low low pay. Faculty is empowered by administration to make decisions and manage things out of their expertise.  Very very frustrating to have a math professor try to educate me on how to install a pump.

cons: Like all things in higher ed things here move SLOWLY! Also, they don't promote from within because they don't want to lose positions but end up doing that anyway b/c their employees leave

pros: I completed a semester long internship with KCTCS and it was really good experience to have.
cons: I can't think of a whole lot of downsides to the internship. Slightly unorganized at times, but management is busy so it's understandable.
